note:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Ativan / lo___
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
orthopnea, rash
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
___ PMH renal cell carcinoma, status post right nephrectomy,
complicated by metastatic pleural nodules and malignant 
effusion,
on chemotherapy, HFrEF, HTN, HLD an atrial flutter/atrial
fibrillation, with admission ___ ___F and
cardiogenic shock in the setting of malignant pericardial
effusion, status post pericardial drain placement and removal
presents with new L lower leg ecchymosis, erythema, and 
swelling,
with worsening orthopnea.
 
He noticed a scratch on his left lower leg on ___. He does 
not
recall any specific injury or trauma to the leg, but thinks he
may have bumped it on a bedside table. Over the next ___ hours, 
he
developed worsening pain, erythema, swelling, and development of
a large ecchymosis of the medial aspect of the lower leg. He has
some peripheral neuropathy at baseline, but has not noticed any
change in sensation of the leg or new weakness. Endorses
intermittent fevers and chills, but no recorded temps at home.
Has noticed several days of dysuria, but denies increased 
urinary
frequency or hematuria. Also with some mild nausea, but no
vomiting, chest pain, or abdominal pain. Last BM was 3 days ago
and was normal.

At the same time, he reports several days of worsening bilateral
leg swelling and orthopnea. Due to accidental omission of Lasix
from his pill organizer, he has not taken the Lasix over the 
past
week. He has home oxygen, but typically only uses it ~1x/week.
His O2 requirement has not increased over the last week.
 
In the ED, initial VS were: 4 98.6 98 114/82 17 94% RA  

Exam notable for:  
Lung sounds are absent at the right bases and faint at the right
upper. Left lung fields all demonstrate fine crackles  
Small area of bruising of the right chest.  
Large hematoma in his left lower extremity but it is not tense.
Biphasic pulses dopplerable bilaterally.  
2+ pitting edema bilaterally  
POCUS echo demonstrates trace pericardial effusion, large volume
ascites, B lines and right upper lung field, probable loculated
fluid in right lower lung field  
 
Labs showed: WBC 14.7, INR 1.6, normal Chem, BNP 2881, lactate
2.7, UA +, flu negative, trop 0.05, MB1  
 
Imaging showed: CTA- negative for PE, progression of right lower
lobe postobstructive collapse as well as mediastinal and right
hilar lymphadenopathy since ___. Loculated right
pleural effusion, right pleural and right chest wall tumoral
deposits, and multiple lytic and expansile osseous metastasis
appear similar to the prior exam.  
No DVT b/l in ___  

Patient received: IV Lasix 40, IV vancomycin and ceftriaxone  

Transfer VS were: 98.1 104 112/71 20 100% 4L NC  

On arrival to the floor, patient confirms the above history. He
endorses significant leg pain and requests pain meds.
 
Past Medical History:
 -Renal cell carcinoma (stage II clear cell) status post right
nephrectomy, complicated by metastatic pleural nodules and
malignant effusion, on axitinib 5 BID, ___: started
nivolumab.  
 CARDIAC HX:  
 -Recent admission ___ ___F and cardiogenic
shock in the setting of malignant pericardial effusion, status
post pericardial drain placement and removal.  
 -Hypertension  
 -Hyperlipidemia  
 -?MI in ___, did not require stents or surgery  
 -A.flutter (had been on warfarin for 5 months in the past)  
 OTHER Medical Hx:  
 - Thyroid nodules  
 - GERD  
 - Colonic polyps  
 - Gallstone pancreatitis ___  
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
His mother had ovarian cancer. One of his rothers died of liver 
cancer. Another brother had ESRD, was on Dialysis, and died of 
complications. His father had a lymph noder emoved and received 
XRT, but the patient does not know the diagnosis. One sister 
passed away due to breast cancer.
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:  
VS: 98.3, 116/87, 65, 22, 96% on 3.5L NC   
GENERAL: Chronically ill appearing. Alert and interactive. NAD.
HEENT: AT/NC, EOMI, PERRL, anicteric sclera, pink conjunctiva,
MMM  
NECK: supple, no JVD
HEART: Irregularly irregular rhythm, non-tachycardic, audible
S1/S2, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. Pulsus 8-___oppler and manual BP cuff.
LUNGS: Breathing comfortably on NC O2. Absent breath sounds at
right base, with decreased breath sounds in upper lung field. 
Few
left basilar crackles. No wheezes or rhonchi.
ABDOMEN: Distended but soft, no tenderness to light or deep
palpation. No organomegaly.
EXTREMITIES: ___ pitting edema to lower thigh bilaterally.
Extensive purpuric, erythematous rash covering medial aspect of 
L
lower leg (borders marked with marking pen). Significant
tenderness to palpation of L lower leg at site of the erythema. 
R
lower leg cool to touch, L lower leg warm.
PULSES: Dopplerable DP and ___ pulses bilaterally. 
NEURO: A&Ox3, sensation to light touch intact in bilateral lower
extremities, strength exam limited due to pain, but able to move
all 4 extremities.

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM:
On exam, patient was non-responsive to voice. His pupils were 
nonreactive to light. He did not withdraw to pain. He had no 
heart or breath sounds. He was
pronounced dead at 04:05 on ___.
 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:
==============
___ 11:18PM   WBC-14.6* RBC-4.34* HGB-12.4* HCT-40.9 MCV-94 
MCH-28.6 MCHC-30.3* RDW-16.9* RDWSD-58.6*
___ 11:18PM   NEUTS-88.1* LYMPHS-5.0* MONOS-6.1 EOS-0.1* 
BASOS-0.2 IM ___ AbsNeut-12.83* AbsLymp-0.73* AbsMono-0.89* 
AbsEos-0.01* AbsBaso-0.03
___ 11:18PM   ___ PTT-36.9* ___
___ 11:18PM   CALCIUM-8.4 PHOSPHATE-3.1 MAGNESIUM-1.6
___ 11:18PM   CK-MB-1 proBNP-2881*
___ 11:18PM   cTropnT-0.05*
___ 11:18PM   CK(CPK)-52
___ 11:18PM   GLUCOSE-91 UREA N-17 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-139 
POTASSIUM-4.3 CHLORIDE-98 TOTAL CO2-27 ANION GAP-14
___ 02:50AM URINE  COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Cloudy* SP 
___
___ 02:50AM URINE  BLOOD-MOD* NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-30* 
GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-6.0 
LEUK-LG*
___ 02:50AM URINE  RBC-17* WBC->182* BACTERIA-FEW* 
YEAST-NONE EPI-0
___ 02:50AM URINE  WBCCLUMP-MANY* MUCOUS-FEW*
___ 03:18AM   LACTATE-2.7*
___ 08:27AM   LACTATE-2.6*

MICRO:
======
No growth of blood, urine (beyond yeast), or peritoneal fluid 
cultures

IMAGING:
========
TTE (___)
The left atrium is markedly dilated. The right atrium is 
markedly dilated. There is moderate symmetric left ventricular 
hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity is small. Overall left 
ventricular systolic function is low normal (LVEF = 50%). There 
is abnormal septal motion suggestive of pericardial 
constriction. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus 
level. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial 
mitral regurgitation. There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial 
effusion. There are no echocardiographic signs of tamponade. The 
echo findings are suggestive but not diagnostic of pericardial 
constriction. 

CXR (___)
Near complete collapse of the right lower lobe with loculated 
right pleural effusion is not appreciably changed on radiographs 
from multiple prior studies dating back to ___, but is 
better assessed on the dedicated same day CTA chest. 

BILATERAL ___ ULTRASOUND (___)
1. The right and left peroneal veins were not detectable. 
Otherwise, no 
evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the right or left lower 
extremity veins. 
2. Subcutaneous edema noted in both the right and left calf. 

CTA CHEST (___)
1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or acute aortic 
abnormality. 
2. Interval progression of complete right lower lobe collapse as 
well as 
mediastinal and right hilar lymphadenopathy since ___. 

3. Multifocal ground-glass opacities in the left lung with 
interval increase in small left pleural effusion likely 
represents component of superimposed pulmonary edema. 
4. Loculated right pleural effusion, right pleural and right 
chest wall 
tumoral deposits, mild pericardial effusion, and multiple lytic 
and expansile osseous metastasis appear similar to the prior 
exam in ___. 
5. Redemonstration of partially visualized celiac axis nodal 
mass. 
6. Partially visualized intra-abdominal ascites may be slightly 
increased 
since the prior study. 

NON-CONTRAST CT HEAD (___)
1. No acute intracranial abnormalities.  Please note MRI of the 
brain is more sensitive for the detection of acute infarct. 
2. Please note contrast brain MRI is more sensitive for the 
evaluation of 
intracranial metastatic disease. 
3. Paranasal sinus disease , as described. 
4. Atrophy, probable small vessel ischemic changes, and 
atherosclerotic 
vascular disease as described. 

ANKLE/FOOT XRAY (___)
No fracture or dislocations are seen around the left foot or 
ankle. There are no significant degenerative changes.  The 
mortise is congruent on these nonweight bearing views.  The 
tibial talar joint space is preserved and no talar dome 
osteochondral lesion is identified. No suspicious lytic or 
sclerotic lesion is identified.  No soft tissue calcification or 
radiopaque foreign body is identified.  There is soft tissue 
swelling noted around the ankle. 

CXR (___)
1. Mild interval increase in the right loculated pleural 
effusion.  In tandem with the mild enlargement of heart size, 
the development of early pulmonary edema is possible. 
2. Unchanged near complete collapse of the right lower lung. 
3. Mild interval increase in left lower lung atelectasis. 

TTE (___)
The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Right ventricular 
chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The mitral valve 
appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. 
There is a small circumferential pericardial effusion without 
definite echocardiographic signs of tamponade. Ascites is 
present. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ ___ s/p r nephrectomy c/b metastatic pleural nodules & 
malignant pericardial effusion s/p pericardial drains, on 
nivolumab, who presented with ___ erythema & worsening 
orthopnea, treated initially as cellulitis subsequently felt to 
be traumatic purpura but hospital course c/b TTE findings 
suggestive of pericardial constriction, fluid overload, 
hypotension and c/f infection of uncertain source. He developed 
anuric renal failure likely in the setting of persistent 
hypotension, and given his multiorgan failure and terminal 
cancer diagnosis, the patient and his family expressed a clear 
preference to transition his care to comfort measures only. 

# GOC
Given his multiorgan failure, terminal cancer diagnosis, and 
lack of remaining medical options to potentially alter his 
prognosis, ___ expressed a clear desire to transition his 
care to comfort-focused care. He was enrolled in inpatient 
hospice, and his pain, dyspnea, and anxiety were managed with 
the help of palliative care. He spent time with his family on 
the day before his death, and died overnight into ___. He was 
pronounced dead at 4:05 am. His family was informed, and they 
expressed gratitude over the care he had received.

# Pericardial Effusion
# Constrictive pericardial disease
Effusion likely malignant c/w prior, presently no e/o tamponade 
physiology by echo but pulsus has been elevated as high as 18. 
Pericardiocentesis ___, pericardiotomy ___. TTE from 
___ with constrictive pericardial disease likely secondary to 
both metastatic disease and multiple previous procedures. 
Stopped monitoring vitals after transition to CMO.

# RCC s/p r nephrectomy c/b metastasis, multiple failed regimens
Previously on Nivolumab (C2D1 = ___. Had recently been on 
Axitinib. After his transition to CMO, he was treated 
symptomatically for his pain, anxiety, and dyspnea.

# Shock
Multifactorial; likely obstructive due to constrictive 
pericardium, possibly septic. Discontinued antibiotics and 
albumin after transition to CMO.

# Malignant Ascites
Patient had significant abdominal ascites secondary to diffuse 
metastatic disease. s/p dx and tx paracentesis ___, without e/o 
SBP by cell count. 4L removed, with 25g albumin post-procedure.

# HFpEF
Exam consistent with fluid overload. However, diuresis made more 
challenging by constrictive pericardium. Discontinued supportive 
albumin after care was transitioned to CMO, as above.

# Leukocytosis w/left shift
Unclear source, but considered UTI vs PNA vs SSTI vs SBP. 
Notably afebrile throughout course. Discontinued ABX with shift 
in care to CMO.

# Anuric ___
Cr 4.1 on last check, up from b/l 0.9, now anuric. New during 
hospitalization, developed during periods of hypotension and as 
patient was increasing in weight. Suspect ATN from hypotension 
vs cardiogenic. Per nephrology, the patient would not be a 
candidate for HD.

# Afib
Previously on apixaban and metoprolol. Metoprolol was held given 
c/f cardiogenic shock.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO BID:PRN Pain - Mild 
2. Apixaban 5 mg PO BID 
3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
4. axitinib 5 mg PO BID 
5. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO EVERY OTHER DAY 
6. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
7. Levothyroxine Sodium 75 mcg PO DAILY 
8. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
9. Omeprazole 20 mg PO BID 
10. Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY 
11. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 
12. OxyCODONE SR (OxyconTIN) 10 mg PO Q12H 
13. melatonin 3 mg oral QHS:PRN insomnia 
14. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY 
15. amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY 
16. Ondansetron ___ mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea 
17. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN moderate 
pain and dyspnea 
18. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
N/A. Deceased.
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
metastatic renal cell carcinoma
malignant pericardial effusion
obstructive shock secondary to constrictive pericardial disease
acute on chronic hypoxic respiratory failure, multifactorial
malignant ascites
acute anuric renal failure
 
Discharge Condition:
deceased
 
Discharge Instructions:
deceased
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
